claim: A video posted to TikTok and Instagram during the January 2024 polar vortex shows a woman in Canada making a helix out of ice by pouring it on the ground in a spiral pattern.
content:
Every few years, when the cold, arctic air of the polar vortex plunges south, internet users around the globe are treated to viral videos about the cold snap. Examples include frozen sculptures made of ramen and clothes as stiff as a board. You can even throw hot water into the air and watch it turn into a white cloud of steam and ice.
TikTok user QueenChelsea wanted to take it a step further in January 2024, posting a video to her TikTok and Instagram page showing her pouring water on the ground and creating a helix out of ice. The video quickly went viral, with over 13 million likes on TikTok (with 191 million views) and over 5 million likes on Instagram. The frozen sculpture looked real enough to fool many commenters, and Snopes received emails inquiring if the video was real.

Unfortunately, Canada being cold was the only real part of the video. Sorry to burst anyone's bubble (another great thing to play with in sub-zero temperatures), although it is certainly a testament to QueenChelsea's editing prowess that some people believed the ice sculpture was real.
QueenChelsea, whose real name is Chelsea Laufer, is a Canadian content creator who makes short viral videos using clever editing tricks and incredible visual effects. She included the VFX hashtag in the captions on both the TikTok and Instagram posts, and her bio on both platforms includes the sentence, "I like making impossible things."
Snopes reached out to Laufer for comment, and she replied via email.
"I’m a visual effects content creator so all of the videos I post are edited with a sort of magical realism in mind," she wrote. "I'll also add that the response to this video has been absolutely astounding! I made this video as a way to practice working with 3D CGI, and I never expected so many people to see it."
On Jan. 18, she posted a video to TikTok breaking down how she made the effect.

original_rationales.main_rationale: Unfortunately, Canada being cold was the only real part of the video.
original_rationales.additional_rationale1: QueenChelsea, whose real name is Chelsea Laufer, is a Canadian content creator who makes short viral videos using clever editing tricks and incredible visual effects.
original_rationales.additional_rationale2: QueenChelsea, whose real name is Chelsea Laufer, is a Canadian content creator who makes short viral videos using clever editing tricks and incredible visual effects.

summary_rationales.synthesized_rationale: The claim regarding the video of a woman in Canada creating a helix out of ice during the January 2024 polar vortex being fake is based on the fact that the video was a result of visual effects, as admitted by the content creator herself. The video's virality was driven by clever editing rather than a real phenomenon. The content creator, QueenChelsea, openly stated that all her videos are edited with 'magical realism', emphasizing the use of CGI in her content production. These admissions directly contradict the authenticity of the video, confirming its falseness.

detailed_reasons.reason1: The content creator, QueenChelsea, specifically mentioned in her responses that she is a visual effects content creator and that the videos she posts are edited with a 'magical realism' approach. This acknowledgment directly indicates that the video in question was a product of visual effects and editing rather than a genuine occurrence.
detailed_reasons.reason2: QueenChelsea's statement about the immense response to the video and the purpose of creating it to practice working with 3D CGI further solidifies the understanding that the helix ice creation was not real. This admission highlights the intent behind the video's creation and reinforces the use of digital effects to achieve the presented phenomenon.
detailed_reasons.reason3: The presence of the VFX hashtag in the captions of the TikTok and Instagram posts by QueenChelsea, along with her bio mentioning 'making impossible things', serves as clear evidence that the video was constructed using visual effects techniques. These intentional cues provided by the content creator emphasize the artificial and edited nature of the content, supporting the 'Fake' rating.
